awd_abstract_narration:
The Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (GRWC) will be held in Minneapolis, MN (2020), Denver, CO (2021) and Ames, IA (2022), building upon successful NSF-funded workshops from 2014 to 2019. Each workshop will involve approximately 45 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in an intense two-week collaborative research experience. Participants will work to solve important problems from across the modern subdisciplines of combinatorics, including algebraic combinatorics, graph theory, enumeration, combinatorial matrix theory and finite geometry. Students will prepare open problems prior to the workshop under the guidance of faculty mentors from institutions around the United States. These problems will be investigated by small groups of participating students, postdocs, and faculty. 

The goal of the collaborations at the heart of the GRWC is to produce high-quality, publishable research on a variety of topics. Another longer-term goal of the workshop is to help student and postdoctoral participants expand their professional research networks. A strong research network is often a crucial part of building a generative and sustainable research program, and establishing these connections at an early career stage can have a long-term positive effect on the quality, impact, and depth of a professional's research portfolio. Participation in the GRWC will allow students to cultivate a large network of peers from the combinatorics community with whom they will be able to interact and collaborate throughout their careers. The GRWC will also offer professional development workshops to help students and postdocs prepare for their future careers in academia, industry and government. For more information about the GRWC, including a detailed description of the workshop format, please see the workshop website at www.combinatoricsworkshop.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Graduate Research Workshop in Combinatorics (GRWC) is an annual two-week summer workshop that brings together 35-60 participants to engage in intense research on open problems in combinatorics. This grant helped support the workshop over four summers (extended from the original plan for three due to changes brought about by the pandemic. This included the 2021 workshop held virtually; the 2022 workshop held in Denver, CO; the 2023 workshop held in Laramie, WY; and the 2024 workshop held in Milwaukee, WI.

The research topics explored during the workshop come from a wide range of areas in combinatorics. Topics for the years that were covered through this grant included, but were not limited to, topological graph theory, parking functions, matroids, extremal graph theory, algebraic combinoatircs, spectral graph theory, Riordan arrays, graph coloring, computational combinatorics, percolation, permutation statistics, Ramey theory, and posets. The problems are posed, and led, by the participants leading to a wide range of problems which reflect some of the newest ideas and techniques available in combinatorics. To date there have been 27 papers produced from the 2021-2024 workshops (with more expected).

In addition to the research the workshop promotes professional development and networking. The workshop regularly talks with participants about jobs in academia, industry, and national labs. The participants are also introduced to new techniques in combinatorics and the graduate students and postdocs have opportunities to work with faculty who are leaders in their disciplines. The networking aspect has played a particularly important role coming out of the pandemic to help create a sense of community within the mathematical discipline. Many of the participants in the workshop benefit from having the chance to interact and form connections with potential long-term collaborators where their home institution might leave them isolated as they can be the only person working in combinatorics.

More about the workshop, including results coming out of the workshop, can be found online: https://www.combinatoricsworkshop.org/
